First: Create a weekly schedule\n Write out a weekly schedule based on class time activities, free time and job activities
Second: Estimate the average amount needed for each subject to obtain a specific grade
Third: Schedule blocks of free time between subjects and assign them to study a particular subject
Fourth: Write down what you do whilst studying.Examples are breaks, nervousness.\nNote the length of time it takes to get started on the assignment
Monitoring of behaviour can lead to change
A research showed that University students obtaining higher grades reported the following about themselves:
Although Students did not assign themselves a specific time to study each subject, they set aside a specific time to study everyday
They usually studied during the day between classes and made enjoyable activities upon completing a definite assignment
They studied alone
They studied a subject continuously for an hour rather than skipping between subjects
They began working on voluminous assignments long before the due date
They obtained 3–6 hours of exercise each week
They spent less time studying material specific to a subject than students receiving lower grades
SQ3R method is one of the effective ways of transferring reading materials into memory\n The process involves five steps : scan,question,read,recite and review.

Scan
 Look over an entire chapter, attempt to gain a general understanding of what the author is saying.
 Look at major headings and relationships between them. Read the summary as it provides an overview of what the author thinks its important. 
 You can take 5 minutes to complete this activity, picking 5-7 points which are important in the chapter

Question
 What are you about to read? Transform major and minor headings into questions and write them into a notebook. This allows you to review chapters using a problem solving frame of reference. Areas of strengths and weakness could be be identified through this process when revising for an exam. 
 The three types of questions which are important 
 Definitions 
 Similarities and Differences 
 Examples

Read
 Read the chapter carefully now to find answers to questions you have written down You can highlight the answers by the following options: 
 Using a personal notation system in the margin of the chapters to quickly find information when revising. Example I=Important, S=Summary VI=Very Important
 Writing the answers in a notebook under the questions. Use key phrases that will trigger recitation of concepts to avoid lengthy answers in notebook. Focus on these major points when reading a specific chapter
 The fist sentence of the paragraph. The rest of the lines usually explains the main point in the first line
 Take note of graphs,table and charts, they summarize key concepts
 Key Phrases which explain important information follow words like "firstly,secondly, thirdly and summary".
Recite\n Recite answers to questions after reading a whole chapter. This produces a rapid method of learning from both verbal and auditory channel.

Review\n Review material after answering all questions in the chapter. You should take less than 5 minutes to reanswer questions in the chapter from memory. A material that cannot be verbalised is not know.
One hour lectures usually contains 3–6 main points
This section is about lecture notes and preparing for exams, the following can be followed:

Lecturers may present materials in this manner:\n
Present overview of material that will be covered\n State the main points and label them as important

Personal interest of examiner may appear in exams, be aware of them
 Terms such as "being able to apply what you have learnt" implies problem and analogy type questions in exams
 "Knowing the basics" implies short answer and similarities and differences questions. 
 The lecture itself will provide materials for an exam through handouts.

Always organise lecture notes after you write them down. Do the following after lectures: 
 Take a few minutes to skim over notes
 Write down sentences to summarize main points
 Write down points you need clarification for the next lecture

Procedures that can help manage anxiety while preparing to take an exam:
. Arrive early at the test centre 
 Bring the proper materials 
 Avoid discussions with others about possible questions and answers
 If you cannot recall some material during the exam, try not to panic.
